Award.AbstractNarration:
The ongoing revolution in next generation sequencing technologies and large-scale structural genomics projects has led to dramatic increase in genomic sequences and protein structures. This has brought biological research into a data-driven era, where computational methods and facilities are needed for handling and analyzing the huge volumes of data. In this project, the PIs develop a cloud computing infrastructure called A Biology Cloud (ABC) to support research in the areas of bioinformatics and computational biology. ABC is built based on the OpenStack, which is supported by more than 180 large companies and has quickly become the standard for cloud infrastructure. ABC will enable researchers at North Dakota State University (NDSU) to conduct pioneering research in their respective fields and promote and facilitate cross-disciplinary collaborations among them.

In this project, the PIs implement comprehensive educational plans to develop excellent academic programs at NDSU and to provide new research and educational opportunities for students. Through a variety of outreach activities, the PIs introduce modern technologies to high school students and the public to enhance their interest in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The revolution in sequencing technologies and large-scale structural genomics projects has led to dramatic increase in genomic sequences and protein structures. This has brought biological research into a data-driven era, where computational methods are needed for the storage and analysis of huge volumes of data. At North Dakota State University (NDSU), a large group of bioinformatics researchers are conducting cutting-edge research in genomics and computational structural biology. With the support of this NSF CRI:II-NEW award , the PIs have developed a cloud computing facility, named A Biology Cloud (ABC), at the Department of Computer Science of NDSU. The ABC consists of one controller node, five compute nodes, and one storage node. Each compute node has a 12-core CPU and 256 GB RAM, and the storage node has a total capacity of 82 TB. The ABC is implemented using OpenStack (release Mitaka), a free and open-source software platform for cloud computing.  Since its inception, the ABC has been playing an important role in various research projects. Today,  the  ABC has become an essential facility that NDSU researchers can depend on for their pioneering work in the fields of bioinformatics, genomics, and computational structural biology. Furthermore, the existence of ABC has greatly promoted cross-disciplinary collaborations on and beyond the campus.
